commentBody:
[in the voice of professor Farnsworth]

GOOD NEWS EVERYBODY!

Benny the poodle-mutt came home today! The vet and tech said they couldn't believe he's 15 years old because he recovered from surgery so well. He's a bit dopey from the meds, but he's home. His absence, even for just 48 hours, left a void in the house. I want to thank everyone for their support and well wishes.

"You knew that phone number was disconnected!"
"I called it!"

(These puns don't get a good reception.)

Finally, a Fridayish Friday.

Fine debut, Fritz!

Deb,

Keep staying in the day, every day, for many many days.
Challenging! for me, at least. A few sheer guesses (TIARA and BOCCE) and some blind alleys, as well as some I didn't fall for (TAROT) and it came together. My brain felt exercised, in a pleasant way.
A fine Friday puzzle, calibrated perfectly. I was initially stalled in the northeast, until BOCCE dawned on me, and that made all the difference.

SLYBOOBS gave me a guffaw when I tried to live DAY BY DAY.
(Will the emus be okay with this?)

The grid of T‚Äôs was fun. None can compare with the one from 1/9/20 by Alex Eaton Salners, though. Saying no more in case anyone hasn‚Äôt done that one yet.
Some of the cluing was so clever that I actually laughed out loud when I hit the flash point.

Well done. A nice challenge that took me over my average solving time for a Friday puzzle. With my fingers moving faster than my brain, I was felled by a typo! But I learned it's TEETOTALER, not TEATOTALER, because there's no MAA West!

Xwstats.com calls this one Very Hard, with the median solver 27% slower than average.

As I was doing the puzzle, I was indeed expecting just that.  The puzzle came in at about one and a quarter minutes slower than my Friday average, and I had to do a lot more skipping around to get traction than I usually do.

SLY BOOTS is not an expression I've ever used, nor do I think I've seen it.  It's inferrable, but it takes time.  I also didn't know that a British "bog" is a LOO, but of course, it was to be anticipated.  I have never heard the terms "howcatchem" and "splooting," either.  

I did like the clue for NOAH.
As soon as I got DISC, and ADA (Lovelace), it was clear I was dealing with a mathematical constructor.  That helped with OCTAHEDRA, where words ending in A are hard to find.
ok I cheated a whole bunch. But I learned a lot, so it was worth it. SPLOOT!! Can a future puzzle constructor use this please?

Having noticed that the new top-secret Midi comes live at the same time as the regular out-in-the-open puzzles do, I've now done all five of them and noted the two special letters from each.

Since I didn't send away for the special decoder ring, I put the ten letters into an anagram solver and I have found what I think is the "secret message".

It's not "Drink your Ovaltine."

I won't reveal what it is, in case you want to figure it out for yourselves, but I will say I have no idea what the apparent answer is referring to.

Anyone out there with a clue?

It was a bit tricky in plaves much not to bad. The last clue to drop was ebay.

I 'm familiar with squirrels splooting- I've  see them doing this  recently where I live during extra hot days- usually belly down on logs in the woods.

My fill time was about my average to complete a Friday puzzle. I'm not going to mention the 10 extra minutes it took me to find one typo. A cood sort may have pointed it out to me sooner, or at least told me to put my glasses on. 

Goodnight all.

Dial Soap and A.L. batting titles completely threw me in the SW but I enjoyed the puzzle.
Vive la France!
Sadly I didn‚Äôt enjoy this one bit. Played much like a Saturday for me - it was just not on my wavelength at all

AHA MOMENT?

Now that‚Äôs a meta-entry today.

This one was a challenge and took more focus than usual, but I enjoyed it. And I loved learning about splooting! It took me 16% over my average Friday time.

There are few things that make me more nervous than when someone tells me to ACT NORMAL!
If anyone was wondering, the TEETOTAL in this grid is 20.

Congratulations on your debut, Fritz!  A challenging, but enjoyable puzzle with some clever clues.  Got stuck on 5D with ‚Äúslyboobs,‚Äù then wanted 11D to be ‚Äúact natural‚Äù with a rebus. Caught the errors on crosses and made it to the finish line. Looking forward to your next one.  And thank you, Deb, for the shoutout to Colbert, who is not only a great talent, but a truly decent human being (IMHO). Happy Friday!

This puzzle with a striking grid was on the razor‚Äôs edge of delightfully challenging and frustratingly obscure for me.  Luckily my friends PAULA and ARLO and Rod CAREW helped give me just enough purchase to chip away at the puzzle.  Unlike many puzzles it never came together in a rush.  The non-general knowledge clues were wonderfully off kilter, so that uncovering the answer was often a true AHAMOMENT.  And, REGNANT is just a fine, elegant word.  In the end, although I solved it slowly, it suited me to a tee.

As a long-ago math major and later software developer, I appreciated DISCS, TERABYTE, DATA POINT, and the Weird Al reference. I knew I was on the constructor's wavelength when I immediately recognized the "Noted doomsday prepper."
I hope we see more from Mr. Juhnke.

Silent e's.

I can't believe I couldn't see that.  I was so focussed on the s's, I didn't even see the e's.

Fantastic Friday for me. I love a bottoms up puzzle (pun intended) and this was certainly one for me. I had very little in the top half and gradually worked my way up. The NW was last to go for me and required a lot of AHAMOMENTS (TAROT, STUDYDATE). It didn‚Äôt help that I had INAILEDIT before ICALLEDIT.
Also any puzzle that references COLUMBO and Dungeons and Dragons gets a thumbs up automatically.

To Deb: Here's wishing you many, many, many years of day-to-days. All my love to you, and heartfelt thanks for the EPICNESS of your columns (from someone who gets it and also lives day-to-day ;-)) To Fritz: Congratulations on a Friday-worthy debut! So Friday-worthy, in fact, that I stumbled around the grid, I fell, I slithered, I cried for help ‚Äì and I loved it! TIL "howcatchem" and "splooting," so thank you for that. And just today, I was reading about how ALDI has no plans of coming yet to Oregon and Washington [sniff, sniff.] Good thing we have Trader Joe's. The musical accompaniment today is from the 1970s, though it has nothing to do with COLUMBO: https://youtu.be/ekoHxB4idmg?si=8quCXcjrni7hMWhb Thank you for the puzzle, Fritz. Very well done!
This was, at minimum, the fifth-best puzzle so far this week. Maybe even higher than that.

This was a tough one. Had to look up the Sarawat Mountains and the slang meaning of bog. Once I had those two, I was able to work through the rest. 

Thank goodness this one used the correct spelling of bocce.
Deb, I didn‚Äôt know about your diagnosis until today, but so happy you‚Äôve reached (or will soon enough) the five-year mark. Here‚Äôs hoping for decades upon decades more.

‚ÄúSplooting‚Äù made my day. Turns out my dog ‚Äúsploots‚Äù on the deck when the sun is out. (Which it hasn‚Äôt been for weeks in the Bay Area.)

Still annoyed about the stats redesign, though. üò©
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia! Deb! Hats off to you for your great job of living day to day and making all our lives so much nicer.

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Mr. Juhnke!

I found it a bit more challenging than the last few weeks' Friday puzzles ‚àè‚àè‚àè‚Äî almost Saturday-level. (That's a good thing, in my book.) I also thought it had a fresh feel, with few of the repeated answers we so often see.

It helped that I picked up "sploot" in the last few years. When we lived in Austin, we used to laugh at the squirrels splayed on our deck as if they were completely tired out from wildly running around.

I'd like to second your praise for Crosserville. I've used it a few times and in some ways prefer it to the software program I purchased. Anyone who is considering trying puzzle construction should look into Crosserville.

Thanks. I hope we see you back here soon.

Deb, you are an ENGEL.  I came to the column to get some AHAMOMENTS, and there they were.  I was convinced I could not get anywhere in this puzzle until strangely I had filled over three quarters of it.  The SE corner refused to budge, but Deb knew the fills. I had two essentials missing, and all unfolded.

This was a tough one, not just for the SLYBOOTS clues, but for stuff I just didn't know.   I know zip about D&D, and it's been so long since I used a PC that I couldn't remember CTRL (tried it a couple of ways‚Äîno go.  I knew abou staghorn ferns but not about the SUMAC.

Thank you for your dazzling debut, Fritz, and for using the correct spelling of BOCCE. Loved it.
Some delightful cluing in this one!

An excellent puzzle. 

The LATESHOW isn‚Äôt late yet.
Not sure if ANNAL should be considered a word in its singular form. It is almost exclusively used in plural form, and Webster's dictionary also considers the singular to be archaic.

This was a very hard and quite enjoyable puzzle for me. I really liked the clueing - it felt fresh. Some of it defeated me, sure, but that's to be expected from time to time, especially later in the week, given I'm Polish.

The NW quadrant of the puzzle was impossible for me. PAULA and ADA were my only gimmes rhere. For most of the other clues I needed lookups and even some reveals, in the end.

I've never heard of a DOPE SLAP or of SLYBOOTS.

The clue for OCTET was good, but I just couldn't get it. 

I suppose I've heard of STUDY DATEs in American films and TV (I personally never had a single study date, and learning together just generally was not a thing when I was at school), but today I couldn't recall it even with just the T missing...

The clue for DISC stumped me. The thing is, we have the word "dysk" (disk/disc) in Polish, which means generally the same as in English. However, in geometry specifically, we call the region of a plane bounded by a circle not a "dysk" but a "ko≈Ço," which is also our word for wheel. I ended up looking up the answer ü§∑

In the very middle of the puzzle I was confused by SKIN TAG. I googled what it is just now. Oh, those! I have no idea if the thing even has a Polish name (an article on it in Polish, as well as Dutch, is missing on Wikipedia).

I wonder why ALDI, specifically, of all German and European supermarkets, made it on the American market. In Europe Lidl seems to be the most successful chain, and it's my personal favorite.

It's been a while since a Friday puzzle has forced me to work a little bit.

Appreciate you for that, Fritz. Fantastic clueing!

Fritz Juhnke -  Congrats on your impressive debut.  The ‚ÄúT‚Äù grid was interesting and I liked your clues.  TIL ‚ÄúRegnant. I thought it was a fabulous Friday puzzle.  Hopeful you‚Äôre working on a follow up.
Really liked today's puzzle. Usually Friday's are just annoying. Not too many niche trivia, clever clues, giving some lovely aha moments.

What a fantastic way to start my day. I opened the puzzle thinking, ‚ÄúPlease, please, give me a workout,‚Äù and I was *not* disappointed. Such inventive cluing‚Äîa real Friday treat. 

Since we‚Äôre all listing the typos that held us up at the end, mine was at 42A: [When repeated, something often said to be "deep"]. I had just been up till 3am talking with a friend who‚Äôd got talked into a shamanic retreat rife with feathers, camp, and cultural appropriation. ‚ÄúSounds very wOO wOO,‚Äù I had opined. And so wOO wOO, so fresh on my mid, was very resistant to flyspecking. 

Of course, DOO DOO fits much better. 

Have an awesome Friday, everyone.

My two mini schnauzers sploot all the time, heatwave or not. 

19A:  Respectable? Likable? Half decent?
I've been doing the Mini for years, but sorry - it's just become far too US- centric. I'm done.

Found this hard work in an enjoyable way. Always nice to learn something: "howcatchem" was a new one for me. Never seen the squirrels in our garden sploot, though as we have hotter weather now that might change. One nit: had to hold my nose entering DATA POINTS. A trend line is fitted to data points which rarely lie on it because of variability. In fact, a trend line that passes through all data points would be overfitted and have less predictive value

‚ÄúSheer quantity of awesome‚Äù made me smile and just made me well-disposed to the whole puzzle. Loved it. Took me longer than usual and teetotally fun (now that I know the derivation of TEETOTAL it‚Äôs fun to use!). Comments:
1. I call getting wordle in 5 a _win_, thank you very much. 
2. Credit goes to Adam Sandler‚Äôs Chanukah Song for my awareness of Hall of Famer Rod Carew.

Thank you for a very Fridayish Friday, Fritz.  

There was challenge throughout, but the SE nearly ate my lunch.  I was stuck on lilaC where SUMAC belonged, and that caused all sorts of trouble.  It's magical when you finally just erase a word, then get one AHA MOMENT after another.

Now this was a triumph!  Eclectically rooted  in "C".  Traveling in time   (Ancient REGNANT to contemporary DATA
POINT), varied in parts of speech, playful  in tense and sense. Required for me lookups, which made it a great pleasure to learn while solving . 
.

This was not enjoyable and was totally overdone. It's like Dennis Miller wrote most the grid as a vocab flex, then a 12 year old threw in some trashy slang, and then bits of standard crosswordese and trivia were added to finish it.
I do appreciate the minor theme in the SE.
D+ overall.
‚ù§Ô∏è Deb

Well, once again, I stood no chance of solving that without many lookups and AutoCheck. I‚Äôve never heard of at least 5 answers in this puzzle! I‚Äôm also confused about 24A [Brit‚Äôs ‚Äúbog‚Äù]. I thought their LOO was a toilet?

I did appreciate the shoutout to Stephen Colbert and the cool grid design though. And Deb, we‚Äôre all pulling for you!

So here you are, making a puzzle, and you have to come up with a clue for HEAT WAVE.  Who out there, I ask you, would have come up with the magnificent [When squirrels may thermoregulate by splooting]?

This was presaged by the grid of tees itself, which for me, even before filling in the first letter, turned my head and sent the message that this puzzle was made by a constructor with moxie, confidence, and ability.

Speaking of ability, this is a 66-worder, and look how cleanly it is filled in!

Speaking of magnificent out-of-the-box clues:
[How one lives in the face of an inscrutable future]
[Org. that may allow religious headwear in pictures]
[Reduced demand for refrigerated trucking, in a way].

I like the ‚Äúeight‚Äù mini-theme, with OCTET, OCTAHEDRA, and the eight black-square tees.  I also like that TOOK backward rhymes with ‚Äúsploot‚Äù.

I‚Äôm delighted by this new Crosslandia voice that made a puzzle pulsing with personality, which promises sweet solves ahead. 

Congratulations, Fritz, on your NYT debut. You‚Äôve entered with a refreshing splash, and thank you for a splendid outing!
Sheeeeesh. Tricky! Great puzzle tho!
At first pass, I thought I couldn't do it..but when I ended that pass by getting "tee total",  I thought, "yes, I can!" A good Friday workout.

Congratulations of the debut, and for spelling BOCCE correctly. Noticed the interesting grid pattern even before it was "revealed" at 59A,

Not familiar with REGNANT, and have never needed more than four guesses in Wordle (my streak stands at 61354), so I was forced to guess that 15D was BOGEY.

Don't think I've heard SLYBOOTS before, and didn't know "bog" referred to LOO, so another guess there.

Solved this one without assistance in about twenty minutes. A very nice Friday puzzle---unless you're a fan of six-letter words.

One of my favorite clues ever was for NOAH. And I was so busy assuming this would be yet another pop culture icon I didn't know that I didn't even think of it at first. Joke's on me! 

And thanks for the nice German clues, Herr Juhnke. ;)

Couple thoughts, 
in no particular order-

Fritz Juhnke is a fabulous name. 
A bona fide handle if ever there was one.

Blank grid with only T‚Äôs on a Friday?
Kind of a waste with no theme‚Ä¶
Wait, what?

Deep DO_‚Ä¶
ran through the alphabet‚Ä¶
deep doa doa? Dob dob? Doc doc..?
Ah! Brilliant! It‚Äôs poop!

This puzzle was a triumph, 
in part because it broke two (non) rules.
A Friday theme and a double OCTtopi.

Yep, I said it. 
Double OCTopi!

This week was so breezy, 
I woke up hoping and praying for a solve like this.

Took me ages!
Hallelujah!

Have a day filled to the brim
with EPICNESS, all!

Fritz Juhnke ( that name! ) set us up for one!
There is just one word:  EPICNESS.  Great debut.
Some cute answers but overall highly tedious. I had more ‚ÄúI guess?‚Äù reactions to the fill than feeling satisfied.

Best (or worst) thing to read as a teenager in 1972: "Aren't you glad you use Dial? Don't you wish everybody did?"  
That smell will haunt me to my dying day.
Tough but fair, and glad to know that skin tags are benign

Deb,

I remember you sharing the news 
of your diagnosis a few years back.

Your lively, brilliant professionalism makes it
easy for me to imagine it just *poof*
went away, or that it‚Äôs not a great burden for you.
I know better, but you make it easy 
for me to sugarcoat.

I‚Äôm so very thankful that you‚Äôre here.
A friend who greets me as I sip my tea,
ever a ray of positivity, charm and wit.

What a gift you are to us all.

Looking forward to *many* more 
years of days with you.

I gave myself a DOPE SLAP when I finally remembered Rod CAREW to complete this crossword.  

Peter Falk and COLUMBO deserve a little more note, sheer EPICNESS.

A few years from now, I‚Äôll bet puzzlers working through the archives will smirk at TERABYTE defined as [Extra-large storage unit]. ‚ÄúHa!‚Äù they‚Äôll say. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the memory in my granny‚Äôs out-of-date iPhone.‚Äù
Phew! Tough one with some interesting TILs like ‚Äúsplooting‚Äù. Finally had to look up ‚Äúbog‚Äù  to complete a tricky NE corner. I also liked the ‚Äúsemi-theme‚Äù. Great debut - congrats!

Typical tough Friday for me and had to do some look-ups but ended up being an enjoyable workout, with quite a few... AHAMOMENT(s). Was really surprised that there was only one debut answer in this one (SKINTAG). 

And one answer history search was based around our constructor's name and... the string of letters JUHN had never been a part of any answers, but... at least JUH was a part of one answer - JUHO in a 1959 puzzle. So I learned that Juho Paassikivi was a former president of Finland.

And I'll put my puzzle find in a reply. 

...
One of the more difficult fridays I‚Äôve seen in a while. Well over my average, but I‚Äôm certainly not complaining
I didn't get the win music today. Did anyone else experience this?

How does ‚ÄúSLYBOOTS‚Äù not make the tricky clues list? I‚Äôve heard and read‚Äîmillions?‚Äîof words, and spent time in Britain, but never once encountered this word; I can‚Äôt find a literary citation for it.

So many things to like about this puzzle!

First (and foremost), it felt like a "real" Friday puzzle, challenging, but not bang-your-head-against-the-wall hard.

If you've got to put DOO into a puzzle, is there a better way to clue it than was done here?¬† I think not.

Things to learn:¬† Splooting!¬† I've seen this behavior before, but who knew that there was a word for it?¬† And a word that's so fun to say!¬† I hope I see some splooting soon, so I can add this word into heavy rotation and make it a permanent part of my vocabulary.

I play Wordle regularly (not that I care about streaks or anything), but I've never heard anyone use golf terminology for their daily score.¬† But it makes perfect sense!¬† Shoot for a birdie-3 every day, be satisfied with a par-4, sad about a bogey-5.¬† An eagle?¬† Nice if it happens, but don't count on it.¬† Hole in one?¬† The stuff¬†of legends.¬† If someone claims to have more than one in a lifetime, they're probably a "storyteller."¬† Double bogey or worse?¬† It's bad luck to even talk about it.

And REGNANT: a rare postpositive adjective in English.¬† That is, an adjective that comes after the noun, as in "Heir apparent" or "Attorney General".¬† Please use the phrase "Queen REGNANT" whenever you can.¬† You'll feel so smart and elegant.

Thanks, Fritz Juhnke, for a very satisfying solve.

And @Deb, Queen REGNANT of Crosslandia, Wild Woman of Wordplay, may you live long and prosper.

AHAMOMENT is pretty good for [Flash point?] 

But when I first read the clue in an empty grid I was hoping for STRIPCLUB
This was tough but good. Loved the reference to Rod Carew. Slyboots and regnant were new to me. Very nice Friday. Thanks for a great debut!
Just stopping by for the BOCCE/BOCCi comments

Wow, was that a Friday puzzle! Really nicely done. It was hard but tractable, with new-to-me REGNANT causing a lot of consternation, and then SLYBOOTS living somewhat distant from my daily vocabulary.

Quite challenging, even by Friday standards. Loved so many of the  clues. TIL the word ‚Äúsplooting,‚Äù and at an appropriate time since our ‚Äúextreme heat warning‚Äù finally ended this morning after a week (the high today will only be 95). 

Re: 14D and TERABYTE being an extra large storage unit‚Ä¶I got my first computer in 1984, an Epson with 256Kb of RAM and one 5 1/4 inch floppy drive. Each day I‚Äôd have to load my word processing program, eject the disc, then load the one I wrote to. 

At some point‚Ä¶1988?‚Ä¶ I graduated to an IBM desk top with two 3 1/2 inch floppy drives, and a  one-megabyte hard drive. The first time I switched it on, I sat back at my desk in awe, saying aloud, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never fill that drive!‚Äù

I felt like I was in some sort of time warp....SLY BOOTS (a phrase that would be heard in the 1800's) crossing the once-unimaginable TERABYTE ...and the seldom-seen term REGNANT...My head is spinning a little with the EPICNESS of seeing NOAH next to the Three Stooges passing around a DOPE SLAP.  

We're about to get an ALDI here in the suburbs of Jackson, MS.  (Still no Trader Joe's or Macy's.  My brother found this unbelievable, but I pointed out that the state has fewer than 3 million residents--less than the number of people in his immediate neighborhood...)  Well, we didn't move here for the shopping.

I am glad I read the column today--which I don't normally get around to.  It's good to know you are holding your own in the face of CLL, Deb!  It's indeed a challenge to keep one's thinking from racing ahead.  For us, just as PhysicsDaughter has completed cancer surgeries and radiation and regained some of her 'normal life,' her ophthalmologist has declared she needs cataract surgeries...at age 42...while I'm staving it off at 78.  (We had nothing but myopic genes to offer our kids. Oops.  Or SPLOOT!)

Good work for a Friday. Was amused to find DIALSOAP was correct - I stuck it in there on first pass. On the other hand, flash point was not "red carpet". 
Misread "prognosticator" as "procrastinator", so that took a hot minute.
Did we all take a second to appreciate that the E was back at the end of BOCCE?
TGIF, everyone!

A lovely almost-themeless puzzle. Favorite entry: COLUMBO, who I am slightly in love with.

As a TEETOTALer (fifteen months!) I do allow myself the occasional ginger ALE. I wonder if there's a theme to be had in nonalcoholic liquids that sound like alcoholic ones? Root beer, oyster liquor, and...?

Very happy to see "BOCCE" spelled correctly.

Bocce is plural of boccia which means 'bowl' or 'ball'

BOCCI would be broccioli which is a flower/plant bud (broccoli anyone?)

Twice my usual Friday time. Here in the Great Lakes region, the Staghorn Sumac, or baakwaanaatig, is ripening nicely: Time to make Sumacade! Pick the bunches of berries--do not wash; Cover with warm--not boiling!--water; let infuse overnight; strain through cheesecloth remove as many fibers (and bugs) as possible; sweeten to taste and chill. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ccenFp_3kq8&list=RDccenFp_3kq8&start_radio=1

Loved the laugh I got from the marvelous phrase, ‚ÄúWhen squirrels thermoregulate by splooting.‚Äù And then further laughs when I had to look up the term splooting! What a nice gift for a Friday morning.

DOPE SLAP!  I am so dumb!  Could not finish the NE, and it's my own fault.  If only I could have found the word for Queen Elizabeth when I had REG.  I was thinking Elizabeth REGINA, so I wrote in REGINAL.  I didn't think it was a word, but desperate people do desperate things.  REGNANT -- of course!  DOPE SLAP!

The only doomsday preppers I could think of were SURVIVALISTS.  I couldn't get ACT NATURAL out of my head, even when it wouldn't fit.  I was thinking of the TSA not the DMV for the ones who allow the religious headgear.  I didn't understand a word in the squirrel clue and refused to look it up.  Of course I don't know anything about the D8 pieces in D&D.  And NOUNS was really cleverly concealed.  

I had all the AHA MOMENTS I needed everywhere else.  And despite the EPICNESS of my failure today, I loved, loved, loved this puzzle!

So much misdirection! Thought it was a NO CAN DO Friday. I felt stupid (DOPESLAP!), and contagious, but here we are now, entertain us. Way over my average to get the AHA MOMENT but finally put this SLY BOOTS of a Friday puzzle on ice.
I thought NOCANDO might have been banned from the puzzles for being "racist."
You know you‚Äôre in for a ride when one of the only words you get on the first pass is REGNANT.
Relied on Easy Mode more than the usual Friday.

Has PIMPSLAP ever appeared in the puzzle? That, I would have gotten. No worries, because I got mad hits like I was Rod CAREW. (I got the brand new DOO DOO, guaranteed like Yoo-Hoo!) Fine Friday challenge, with one minor mis-step...enshrined in an earworm from The Hooters: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3NqtwAv57_A
It tickles me all over again every time I think of NOAH as a doomsday prepper.  Thanks for the giggle, Mr. Juhnke!
I was really sailing along until I hit the NW corner. My biggest problem was my firm and much-too-long-held conviction that a whack on the head had to be an "uppercut."  Oh well.
Well, today I learned how to spell teetotal! All these years I thought it was teAtotal as in someone who drank tea instead of alcohol.  I don't think I've ever seen the word spelled out.

Excellent Friday puzzle. I like the feeling that it will break my streak and then managing to complete it. Lots I didn‚Äôt know. REGNANT, SLYBOOTS,and others I was aware of but needed plenty of crosses, CAREW, SUMAC.
My first thought for Bog was LOO but hesitated thinking it‚Äôs surely now a dated British schoolboy slang and might be FEN. 
I‚Äôm ashamed to say I did not notice the Tees until the revealer. Very clever construction.
Could not even triple-15-D today. Anyone else in a 58-A about it?

The puzzles this week just keep getting better. What a great Friday; tough but not too fiendish. 
Favourite clue; noted Doomsday prepper. Gave a very unladylike like snort at NOAH.
Needed crosses to get REGNANT, can‚Äôt say Ive ever come across that before. Regina yes.
Shout out to the LATE SHOW. How thin skinned are some ‚Äòpeople‚Äô that they can‚Äôt deal with a comedian?
57a should have been clued "Met Pete?"

Definitely a worth Friday from this end. My time was actually a little longer than my cumulative average, which harks back a few years to when I was a much slower solver. So, probably half again as long as my current usual.

Looked back to see what broke it open for me, but honestly couldn't find one thing that did it, just a slow and steady solve, bit by bit as I found alternative interpretations for clues. Now I see there are no answers in it I had not heard of before except for the expression SLYBOOTS (I kept thinking 'SLY dog'), but it took until the very end to dredge REGNANT up from memory.

This was a perfect Friday puzzle. By the end of the pass I only had a few squares filled in, after a few passes it seemed hopeless, but then slowly it opened up and came together. The noted doomsday prepper answer made me laugh, too. A really nice start to my day.

I don't feel guilty about having to check 1A in Tricky Clues. But after that, I managed to finish one second over my average for a Friday. 

It took me awhile (and crosses) to suss out Rod CAREW; I'm more of an NL fan (that league's batting champ is awarded the Hank Aaron trophy). NOAH, as many have noted, was brilliant.

Years you will have can't be measured by a mean‚Äîthe middle of a range after you ignore the highs and the lows‚Äî It has nothing to do with you, and is pointless anyway.

I looked in my dictionaries for some word history on  DOPESLAP. I didn‚Äôt find anything (neither one even lists it), but I did find an interesting word history for ‚Äúdope‚Äù:

The word dope originated in American English and is a borrowing of the Dutch word doop, ‚Äúsauce.‚Äù (New York City was once a Dutch colony, New Amsterdam, and many words originally distinctive to American English, like boss and cookie, were borrowed from Dutch colonists in the region.) Throughout the 1800s, dope meant ‚Äúgravy,‚Äù and in the North Midland United States, particularly Ohio, dope is still heard as the term for a topping for ice cream, such as chocolate syrup or fruit sauce. Also in the 1800s, the meaning of dope was extended to include various medicinal mixtures or syrups, including the syrups from which soda-fountain drinks like Coca-Cola were prepared. A continuation of this usage survives in the South, particularly in South Carolina, where dope refers to the carbonated soft drink that elsewhere in the United States is called cola. Dope was especially used of those medicinal preparations that produced a stupefying effect, and it even became a slang term for the dark, molasses-like form of opium that was smoked in opium dens. The common modern meanings of dope, ‚Äúa narcotic substance‚Äù and ‚Äúnarcotics considered as a group,‚Äù developed from this use of the word.
